thread.title: 'Slimeballs' - Tory Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton goes on election attack | Leicester Mercury
thread.title_full: 'Slimeballs' - Tory Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton goes on election attack | Leicester Mercury

title: 'Slimeballs' - Tory Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton goes on election attack | Leicester Mercury
text:
'Slimeballs' - Tory Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton goes on election attack By danjmartin | Posted: March 25, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Nick Rushton on the attack 'Slimeballs' - Tory Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton goes on... X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Leicestershire County Council leader Nick Rushton has described the Liberal Democrats as "slimeballs" in a speech to Tory councillors and candidates. 
Coun Rushton rounded on his rivals ahead of the May 4 election as he launched the party's manifesto today. 
He said of the Lib Dems, who make up the council's main opposition group: "They are slimeballs. They will just lie. 
"They lie and they cheat and they have a policy for every side of the road. 
"The Liberals are absolutely desperate. They have no policies, no strategies." 
Leicestershire County Council elections 2017: Click HERE for everything you need to know 
He added: "They are dishonest and they are financially incompetent. 
"We can't be remoaners like the stupid Liberals. 
"We have to get in with it (Brexit) and get the best deal available." 
He went on to say Labour was in "serious difficulty" and UKIP was a busted flush. 
Lib Dem opposition group leader councillor Simon Galton said the leader's comments demonstrated how concerned he was about the challenge he faced. 
He said: "It is clear they (the Tories) see us as the main opposition. 
"We feel optimistic. The mood is changing. We have moved on from the Coalition years with the Tories. 
"We will fight this election by attacking the policies, not the personalities. 
"We will run a positive campaign, but we will expose the 16 years of Tory control. 
"They still have Â£60 million of savings to find, but have already done a handbrake turn on cuts to rural bus subsidies. 
"It's disappointing that Nick says these things and there's some forked tongue because he was only saying in council this week how well he had worked with me and (Labour group leader) Robert Sharp."
